Description: The State of California, Office of Technology and Solutions Integration (OTSI), is releasing a Request for Proposal (RFP) #73040873 for System Development, Maintenance & Operations (SDMO) for the California Healthcare Eligibility, Enrollment and Retention System (CalHEERS). There will be a mandatory in-person Bidders Conference held on October 15, 2025. Please note: the conference will begin at 9:30 a.m. so please allow time for sign-in. The CalHEERS Project supports the enhancement, maintenance and operations, and on-going business of both Covered California and the Department of Health Care Services (DHCS). CalHEERS supports account creation, consumer application, eligibility rules, and health plan selection for insurance affordability programs, streamlining Californian's ability to research, compare, check their eligibility for, and purchase health coverage. CalHEERS interfaces with the Statewide Automated Welfare Systems (SAWS) for Modified Adjusted Gross Income (MAGI) Medi-Cal eligibility, enrollment and reporting, and provides data for potential eligibility to other programs such as, non-MAGI Medi-Cal, CalFresh, and California Work Opportunities and Responsibility for Kids (CalWORKS). 10/31/2025 - CalHEERS RFP #73040873 Addendum 1 and Responses Release 01 have been posted. Please refer to RFP Section 1.4, KEY ACTION DATES AND TIMES, for updated due dates.

Event Name: SyS Consulting Agreement
Description: ***Questions and Answers posted 11/4/2025*** ***Addenda 1-3 posted 11/4/2025*** The California Department of Public Health (CDPH) is soliciting proposals from firms that have extensive demonstrated knowledge and experience that would enable them to provide specialized services to support the statewide launch of the new California Syndromic Surveillance Program (CalSyS). The Contractor is primarily responsible for: a. Contributing to the CalSyS program launch, including leading strategic planning and the development of program roadmaps and timelines; supporting the development of program staffing structures, the delineation of duties and responsibilities, and new team member onboarding protocols, trainings, and supportive materials; developing program budget analyses and tracking and monitoring processes; adhering to state legislative and regulatory requirements; and creating standard operating procedures (SOPs) for specified program efforts (e.g., administration and maintenance of California's chosen syndromic surveillance system); and developing program evaluation plans, goals, objectives, metrics, and processes; b. Supporting the onboarding of hospital facilities to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) National Syndromic Surveillance Programs (NSSPs) BioSense platform through quality control and report validation to ensure adherence to reporting requirements; querying, mining, and manipulating syndromic surveillance (SyS) data to support the development of customized research data queries and canned research data sets; and provisioning SyS user access and trainings; and c. Researching the capabilities, resources, requirements, and structures of SyS programs/systems in other states and jurisdictions to draft recommendations and requirements for the CalSyS program's future expansion potential within a comprehensive CalSyS interoperability feasibility plan and report; provide high-level technical consultation regarding syndromic surveillance, informatics, and tools and resources that can be used to achieve CalSyS program goals (i.e., having a cost-effective statewide system that can be used to meet related reporting requirements and monitor emerging public health threats so that data-driven actions can be implemented as needed to promote health and wellness throughout communities in California). This support will help facilitate the launch and establishment of the new CalSyS program and will facilitate the necessary accelerated onboarding of hospital emergency departments statewide to the CDC NSSP BioSense Platform and/or California's identified syndromic surveillance system, enabling these facilities to meet new California legislation and regulation requirements, and providing CDPH and local health departments (LHDs) with timely access to critical comprehensive emergency department data and analytical tools that will increase state and local situational awareness; enhance preparedness and response efforts; and inform the program design, implementation, and evaluation of public health initiatives. Proposals must address all the services described in Exhibit A entitled, "Scope of Work". CDPH intends to make a single contract award to the most responsive and responsible firm offering the highest scoring bid. This procurement is open to all eligible firms and/or individuals that meet the qualification requirements, including commercial businesses, nonprofit organizations, State or public universities (including auxiliary organizations) and other entities.

Event Name: CDCR @ Chino Farming Lease ±700 Acres

Pre Bid Conference.Location: Location details provided on to confirmed and security cleared attendees who RSVP.

Description: The California Department of General Services (DGS) on the behalf of the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR), collectively referred to as ¿State¿, welcomes farming, effluent disposal, and sustainable land management lease proposals for approximately seven hundred (700) acres of farmland and open space at the California Institution for Men (CIM). The CDCR identified State-owned land available for farming activities at CIM. The current land use includes a farming operation to grow, rotate, maintain, and harvest sellable fodder and other crops. The fodder crops are grown as part of the effluent disposal effort to mitigate nitrates in ground water. The remaining crops are grown using irrigation wells and recycled water. The CIM land is identified in ¿Attachment A¿ (CIM Farmable Land and Open Space). CDCR requests bidders identify the Open Space as areas that the bidder will maintain. This opportunity requires Bidders to submit a ¿Sustainable Land Management Plan¿ (SLMP) outlining its operation and plan to maintain land that is not farmed. The SLMP terms are negotiable provided the plan includes farming, effluent disposal, ground water recharge efforts, land management activities, and best efforts to support the Chino Basin via policies implemented by the Chino Basin Watermaster. While Bidders are not required to lease the CIM Open Space, the SLMP must identify CIM Open Space as being managed and maintained by the Lessee. CDCR/CIM is an Agricultural Pool Member under the management of the Chino Basin Watermaster, so Bidders must be willing to support the Agricultural Pool¿s mandates such as safe yield adjustments, groundwater recharge efforts, best practices for water conservation, and nitrate mitigation. Bidders may identify partnering arrangements with Inland Empire Utility Agency (IEUA) and the City of Chino to manage IEUA¿s and the City¿s recycled water and groundwater recharge efforts on the CIM leased area. However, those arrangements must be approved by both CDCR and the Chino Basin Watermaster. Irrigation water is sourced by both CIM effluent disposal and irrigation wells. The CIM irrigation infrastructure is identified in ¿Attachment B¿ (CIM Irrigation and Wells). The State does not guarantee water availability, quality, or quantity. The State requires the Lessee to provide comprehensive, sustainable land management, and maintenance. Land management shall include weed abatement for fire control and mosquito abatement on all CIM Open Space, whether farmed, grazed, vacant, leased, or not leased. A Bidder will be considered a ¿Qualified Bidder¿ after meeting all the Bidder requirements outlined in this RFP including, but not limited to, following instructions for submission, meeting established timelines, clearing a security background check, attending the mandatory walk-through, and providing a SLMP that identifies how the Lessee will: 1) manage the CIM Open Space in its entirety to eliminate maintenance and weed abatement costs for CDCR; 2) manage effluent disposal for CDCR; and 3) Identify the Lessee¿s farming operation including the plan to grow, rotate, maintain, and harvest sellable fodder and other crops. The Qualified Bidder must: 1) Have the authority to enter into a ground lease agreement with the State of California on the State¿s property. 2) Outline details of Bidder¿s farming operation irrigating the Bidder¿s crops in the proposed SLMP. 3) Obtain all necessary permits from the appropriate agencies for the proposed operations. 4) Provide and maintain all equipment required to plant, cultivate, irrigate, and harvest crops. 5) Mitigate fire risks by initiating fire safety and risk mitigation practices including equipment safety training, implementing operational safety standards, conducting weed abatement, and other land maintenance activities. Please take the time to carefully read the proposal requirements. In submitting proposals, Bidders must comply with the instructions herein. All proposals submitted for consideration must be received by the date specified on the cover page labeled ¿SUBMISSION DUE DATE¿ December 19, 2025. If part of the SLMP includes livestock grazing, Bidders must include an overview of the grazing operation and provide a livestock management plan as an attachment to their bid. Submittals and all other materials included will not be returned. All submittals will become public records upon bid award. If a submittal includes proprietary information exempt from public disclosure, it should be clearly designated as such so that a claim of exemption may be made in response to a public disclosure request. No assurances can be given, however, that any information so designated would not ultimately be deemed subject to public disclosure. The State reserves the sole right and privilege to judge the responses to the Bidders¿ RFPs based on evaluation criteria, and to accept a submittal or to reject any or all submittals. The State also reserves the right to cancel in whole or in part this RFP and to waive immaterial defects and minor irregularities in submittals. This RFP is not a contract or a commitment of any kind on the part of the State and does not commit the State to award. In no event shall the State be responsible for any real estate brokerage fees.

Contractor applying, or spraying disinfectant shall also be registered with each individual county agricultural commission where the disinfectant will be applied. Pre Bid Conference.Location: Must Check In at the Capital Facilities Management Services Office upon arrival for the walkthrough.
Pre Bid Conference.Comments: See Attachments for Service Vehicle Permit Application to be completed before the scheduled site visit. A parking permit will be required to park in any campus parking lot. Please see attached document detailing the parking options for the sitewalk.

Description: CSUB-RFP-11008 Numenor & Rohan Roof Replacement Project# PR9126 The Trustees of the California State University will receive sealed bid proposals in the Administration West Building Room 102, at the above address, for furnishing all labor and materials for construction of the above-named Project, Project Number PR9126 for the Bakersfield Campus. Proposals will be received in the above-mentioned room until 3:00 p.m. on Thursday November 13, 2025 in accordance with the proposal documents. The proposal must be submitted on the Bid Proposal Form provided by the University, filled out and sealed in an envelope. Proposals will be publicly opened and read. In general, the scope of work includes all materials, labor, equipment, and services necessary to complete the Roof Replacement of the Numenor Residence Hall in accordance with the plans and specifications prepared by Radian Design Group Inc.unless specifically excluded. The Roof Replacement of the Rohan Residence Hall is an Additive Alternate. Radian Design Group, Inc. 11109 River Run Boulevard, Suite 110 Mark Russell mrussell@radiandesign.net Architect¿s construction estimate for Numenor Residence Hall is $225,000.00 Architect¿s construction estimate for Rohan Residence Hall additive alternate is $211,000.00 Scoping documents, Plans, specifications, and other project/contract related documents will be available electronically. Please contact Andrew Duncan, aduncan@csub.edu to be added to the distribution list if your company would like to participate. Contractors will receive an updated packet that includes all original forms necessary to bid upon attending the mandatory pre-bid walkthrough. A mandatory pre-bid walkthrough has been scheduled for Thursday 10/23/2025 at 10:00 am. Interested bidders must check in at the Capital Facilities Management Services Office upon arrival for the walkthrough. A parking permit will be required to park in any campus parking lot. Please see attached document detailing the parking options for the sitewalk. Please place parking permit prominently in windshield. Each bidder offering a proposal must comply with Bidding provisions of Article 2.00 et seq. in the Contract General Conditions. The Trustees require the successful bidder to achieve three percent (3%) DVBE participation in contracting construction projects as established in the bidding documents, and bidders shall identify the DVBEs to be used to satisfy this requirement in their bids. The Trustees are granting a DVBE Bid Incentive, for bid evaluation purposes only, in accordance with the Contract General Conditions (for Design-Bid-Build Minor Projects, Article 2.11). Bidder shall indicate whether or not Bidder is requesting the DVBE Bid Incentive by checking the appropriate response below. Bidder commits to subcontract at least the percentage of DVBE participation of its net bid price as stated hereon with one or more DVBE(s). Bidders shall contact the Trustees¿ DVBE Coordinator at aduncan@csub.edu. The level of DVBE incentive will correlate to the level of participation; that is, the more DVBE participation proposed, the higher the incentive. Each bidder shall be familiar with all the provisions of the Contract General Conditions and Supplementary General Conditions. This project is a public works project and is subject to prevailing wage rate laws (Contract General Conditions, Article 4.02). All contractors and all tiers of subcontractors who will work on this project shall register to bid and work on public works projects with the Dept. of Industrial Relations, and maintain current this registration pursuant to Labor Code section 1725.5. For more information, go to http://www.dir.ca.gov/Public-Works/PublicWorks.html. It will be the responsibility of each bidder to obtain a bid proposal package in sufficient time to fulfill requirements therein. Bid proposal packages are obtainable only by contractors, licensed in the State of California with either a B or C-39 license and registered with the DIR to bid public works projects, and attended the mandatory job walk. The bid packages must be requested from the Trustees, located at CSU Bakersfield, Attention: aduncan@csub.edu. The time period for completion of the overall project shall be 45 calendar days from the construction start date as stated on the Notice to Proceed. Liquidated damages shall be $500 for each calendar day completion is delayed beyond the time prescribed for the project. For additional information about the bid process contact Andrew Duncan (661) 654-3182 or e-mail at: aduncan@csub.edu. Submit technical questions in writing to Andrew Duncan by end of day November 5, 2025. Event Name: Request for Information (RFI) 20A0386 - Local Assistance Project Management System (LAPMS)
Description: This Request for Information (RFI) is released by the State of California, Department of Transportation (Caltrans), Division of Procurement and Contracts (DPAC), on behalf of the Information Technology Project Management Office (IT PMO) and Division of Local Assistance (DLA). For the purpose of this RFI, `the State¿ refers to Caltrans, acting on behalf of the State of California. This RFI is not a solicitation. This RFI is issued solely for information gathering purposes to support Caltrans in understanding available solutions, industry trends, and best practices. This RFI does not constitute a solicitation for bids, proposals, or offers. No contract award will directly result from responses to this RFI. Participation in this RFI is voluntary, and responses will be used for planning purposes only. The purpose of this RFI is to gather information from the vendor community regarding available project/workflow management solutions that can address the evolving needs of Caltrans. Caltrans is seeking to understand the current marketplace, industry capabilities, and potential technology solutions that align with current and evolving business needs for Local Assistance Project Management System (LAPMS). The Local Assistance Program (LAP) in the Division of Local Assistance (DLA) oversees over $4 billion annually made available to nearly 600 local agencies, including cities, counties, and regional agencies. The LAP is responsible for tracking and managing the federal and state transportation funding programs and over 4,400 active projects. Each local assistance project requires programming, funding authorization, management, and oversight to ensure that the funds are spent under program requirements without exceeding allocation or budget authority. Once funding has been authorized, the LAP guides local agencies and monitors project implementation to make sure the projects are implemented promptly to achieve program goals. For more information, please see the Division of Local Assistance. The system currently supporting LAP responsibilities is Local Programs 2000 (LP2000). LP2000 is an internally facing system, which means none of the functionality is extended beyond internal Caltrans users to the nearly 600 local agencies. LAP staff use LP2000 to create 1,400 new local projects annually, assign the Federal Project Number, and maintain general project information. LP2000 also assembles, generates, and tracks multiple letters and agreements. LP2000 interfaces with key applications including California Transportation Improvement Programs System (CTIPS), Caltrans¿ financial management system (Advantage), and a system for Disadvantage Business Enterprise (B2GNow). Caltrans is seeking to implement a solution that will modernize program operations by introducing automated workflows and real-time data validation, enhancing accessibility, offering integrated reporting tools, and integrating with existing infrastructure. ************************************************** Addendum 1 has been released to provide Caltrans' responses to all questions received. ************************************************** Addendum 2 has been released to extend the RFI due date from 10/31/2025 to 11/14/2025.

Event Name: HSR25-26 Invitation for Bids for Long Welded Rail
Description: 10/24/2025: Addendum 1 for Long Welded Rail has been posted here on Cal eProcure. The Authority's responses to Round 1 of Questions and Responses have also been posted here on Cal eProcure. The procurement schedule has also been updated below: - IFB Released: October 2, 2025 - Bidder Questions Due: October 17, 2025 - Responses to Bidder Questions (Round 1) posted: October 24, 2025 - Addendum 1 released: October 24, 2025 - One-on-One Meetings: November 10 - 14, 2025 - Bidder Questions to Addendum 1 due: November 18, 2025 - Addendum 2 released: November 21, 2025 - Bidder Questions to Addendum 2 due: December 2, 2025 - Responses to all Bidder Questions posted: December 5, 2025 - Bids Due: December 18, 2025 (12:00pm Pacific) - Bid Opening: December 18, 2025 (2:00pm Pacific) - Anticipated Notice to Proceed: Q1 2026 Questions regarding this procurement should be submitted to Kathryn Talattad at materialpurchase@hsr.ca.gov or (916) 324-1541. 10/02/2025: The California High-Speed Rail Authority (Authority) has released an Invitation for Bids (IFB) to purchase commoditized rail materials necessary to complete the First Construction Section of its high-speed rail track. No Pre-Bid Conference or Small Business Workshop is anticipated for this procurement. The timeline for this procurement is as follows: - IFB Released: October 2, 2025 - Notice of Intent to Bid to the Authority Due (mandatory): October 10, 2025 - Bidder Questions Due: October 17, 2025 - Meeting with Authority: October 27-31, 2025 - Authority Responses to Questions due: November 5, 2025 - Anticipated Addendum to IFB due: November 12, 2025 - Bidder Questions to Addendum due: November 17, 2025 - Authority Responses to Addendum Questions due: November 21, 2025 - Bids Due: December 9, 2025 (12:00 pm Pacific) - Bid Opening: December 9, 2025 (2:00 pm Pacific) - Notice of Proposed Award: TBD Questions regarding this procurement should be submitted to Kathryn Talattad at materialpurchase@hsr.ca.gov or (916) 324-1541. 08/22/2025: The California High-Speed Rail Authority (Authority) will be releasing a new Invitation for Bids (IFB) to purchase commoditized rail materials necessary to complete the First Construction Segment of its high-speed rail track. A draft IFB is available for review as an attachment to this Cal-eProcure event. This draft IFB will be considered for approval and official release by the Authority's Board of Directors at its meeting scheduled for August 28, 2025, and is subject to change and approval by the Authority's Board of Directors. Posting of this draft IFB does not constitute acceptance of bids. The draft IFB or its approval, if granted by the Board of Directors, does not constitute a release of the final IFB. Release of the final IFB will occur via notice and posting on Cal-eProcure. Questions regarding this procurement may be submitted only upon final approval of IFB by the Board of Directors and release on the California State Contract Register. Each materials contract will be issued through multiple Notices to Proceed (NTPs) as described below. The estimated cumulative value for all materials contracts (steel OCS poles, rail, concrete ties, ballast, OCS system components, and fiber optic cable) is not-to-exceed $507.1 million for NTP 1. - NTP 1: The initial authorization to be issued for the manufacture and supply of Materials for use in construction on the 119-mile First Construction Section. - NTP 2: To be issued at the Authority's option for the manufacture and supply of Materials for use in construction on the northern extension (Merced to Madera). - NTP 3: To be issued at the Authority's option for the manufacture and supply of Materials for use in construction on the southern extension (Poplar Avenue in the County of Kern to Bakersfield). The scope of work for this specific procurement and resulting contract is to provide Long Welded UIC 60 E1 rail materials, for use in construction on the 119-mile First Construction Section, with an estimated lead time of six to twelve months for NTP 1. General requirements for each material are provided in the IFB and draft agreement. The Contractor shall not perform any Work unless the Authority, in its sole discretion, issues a Notice to Proceed (NTP) and Purchase Order for such work. The actual amount of Work requested by the Authority is subject to the availability of funding. In addition, all materials must be newly manufactured goods and conform to the technical specifications provided by the Authority. All materials supplied must be Buy America and Build America, Buy America Act (BABA) compliant, in accordance with 49 U.S.C. § 22905 and 2 C.F.R. part 184. Information regarding the Pre-Bid Conference and Small Business Workshop is available on the Authority's Website. The anticipated schedule for this new procurement is as follows: - IFB Release: Q4 2025 - Virtual Pre-Bid Conference: TBD - Bid Due/Opening Date: TBD - Notice of Proposed Award: TBD - Anticipated Contract Execution and Notice to Proceed: TBD Questions regarding this procurement should be submitted to Kathryn Talattad at materialpurchase@hsr.ca.gov or (916) 324-1541.

Event Name: HSR25-27R1 Invitation for Bids for Concrete Ties
Description: 10/30/2025: The California High-Speed Rail Authority (Authority) has released an Invitation for Bids (IFB) to purchase commoditized Monobloc Concrete Ties, necessary to complete the First Construction Section of its high-speed rail track. The active contract number for this procurement remains HSR25-27. No Pre-Bid Conference or Small Business Workshop is anticipated for this procurement. The timeline for this procurement is as follows: - IFB Released: October 30, 2025 - Bidder Questions Due: November 13, 2025 - Requests for meetings with Authority Due: November 18, 2025 - Authority Responses to Questions due: November 21, 2025 - Meetings with Authority: December 2-5, 2025 - Addendum (anticipated) to be posted: December 11, 2025 - Bidder Questions to Addendum due: December 19, 2025 - Authority Responses to Addendum Questions due: January 9, 2026 - Bids Due: January 22, 2026 (12:00 p.m. Pacific) - Bid Opening: January 22, 2026 (2:00 p.m. Pacific) - Notice of Proposed Award: Q1 2026 Questions regarding this procurement should be submitted to Trevor Newhouse at materialpurchase@hsr.ca.gov or (916) 324-1541. 10/15/2025: The California High-Speed Rail Authority (Authority) will soon be releasing a new Invitation for Bids (IFB) to purchase Monobloc Concrete Ties, necessary to complete the First Construction Segment of its high-speed rail track. Please note that this procurement will be released under HSR25-27R1. The draft IFB was posted as HSR25-27 for early review purposes only. The scope of work for the procurement and resulting contract is to provide concrete ties with proven design for axle loads of 18tons (tons) for train speeds from 220 km/h up to 354 km/h for NTP 1 materials, for use in construction on the 119-mile First Construction Section, with an estimated lead time of one to two months for NTP 1. General requirements for each material will be provided in the IFB and draft agreement. The Contractor shall not perform any Work unless the Authority, in its sole discretion, issues a Notice to Proceed (NTP) and Purchase Order for such work. The actual amount of Work requested by the Authority is subject to the availability of funding. In addition, all materials must be newly manufactured goods and conform to the technical specifications provided by the Authority. All materials supplied must be Buy America and Build America, Buy America Act (BABA) compliant, in accordance with 49 U.S.C. § 22905 and 2 C.F.R. part 184. Questions regarding this procurement should be submitted to Trevor Newhouse at materialpurchase@hsr.ca.gov or (916) 324-1541.

Event Name: BLANKET ADVERTISEMENT FOR VARIOUS MINOR CAPITAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS (NOT for a specific project) 2025-2026
Description: BLANKET ADVERTISEMENT FOR VARIOUS MINOR CAPITAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS (NOT for a specific project) Contractors who submit the form linked below will be added to a bidders list, and will receive notification from CSUDH on new bidding opportunities for minor capital projects. California State University, Dominguez Hills, is seeking qualified General Contractors holding either Class A, B, and/or C licenses, to perform various jobs and/or minor capital projects as needed through June 30, 2026. The University shall establish a shortlist of qualified contractors for possible future minor cap projects. The maximum dollar value of any individual minor capital project will not exceed $1,103,000.00. Contactors selected for award must be able to readily mobilize and begin work on such projects with a short timeframe; ten (10) to fifteen (15) calendar days; All projects require payment of prevailing wage rates for Los Angeles County, bonds, insurance, and mandatory 3% DVBE participation, and contractors are required to perform the work in compliance with CSU Contract General Conditions for Design-Bid-Build (Minor Capital Projects) and Supplemental General Conditions available at: https://www.calstate.edu/csu-system/doing-business-with-the-csu/capital-planning-design-construction/Documents/cgc_dbb_minor.pdf. The University shall establish a shortlist of qualified contractors and service providers for a variety of services including but not limited removal, replacement, repair, remodel, renovate, construct or maintain facilities, may include, but are not limited to, demolition, site improvements, remodels, flooring, glazing, painting, lathing and plastering, roofing, sheet metal, mechanical, plumbing, electrical, telecommunications, fire alarm, fire sprinkler, security and surveillance systems, etc. Licensed contractors interested in bidding on possible upcoming projects and wishing to be placed on a campus-maintained registry shall submit a Prospective Vendor Registration Form found in the link below. https://forms.microsoft.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=J6dmGolzJ0eoy_JJrI5_-MfmcR8t3ddCiw4cZoQ92M1UQkJST1VISUVIQVFNUzE5WVVYSTg2WkpVSi4u The form must be fully completed, and include the contractor license number, license classification(s), any DVBE or small business certification number, area(s) of expertise and target project size. The Trustees are required to achieve a minimum goal of 3% DVBE and 25% Small Business Enterprise participation in contracting construction projects. Important Notice: California law (SB854) provides that "A contractor or subcontractor shall not be qualified to bid on, be listed in a bid proposal, subject to the requirements of Section 4104 of the Public Contract Code, or engage in the performance of any contract for public work, as defined in this chapter, unless currently registered and qualified to perform public work pursuant to Labor Code Section 1725.5." Please go to https://www.dir.ca.gov/Public-Works/PublicWorks.html for more information and to register. CSU DOMINGUEZ HILLS WILL NOT ADVERTISE THIS WORK ON A PROJECT-BY-PROJECT BASIS. THIS WILL BE THE ONLY ADVERTISEMENT MADE FOR THE CURRENT PERIOD July 1, 2025 THROUGH June 30, 2026. Thank you for your interest in becoming a prospective vendor for California State University, Dominguez Hills. We look forward to your participation in upcoming events!

Event Name: 2025 Annual State Coastal Conservancy Request for Qualifications and Information
Description: The State Coastal Conservancy ("Conservancy") acts to preserve, restore, and enhance California's coastal and marine resources, enhance their resilience to climate change, and to expand public access to the coast. The Conservancy annually updates a list of environmental, engineering, architectural, landscape architectural, construction project management, and the other consulting service providers. This year, we also invite individuals, firms, non-profits, and community groups involved with community engagement, tribal engagement, community-based restoration, traditional ecological knowledge, and other justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion topics to submit their information. The list is used in two ways: to identify consulting firms and individuals with appropriate qualifications for Conservancy consultant needs; and to help us make connections with local organizations and individuals engaged with coastal issues and communities in our jurisdiction. We welcome individuals, consultants, firms, and community groups to submit their qualifications and/or organizational information by filling out the Request for Qualifications and Information Submittal form (https://forms.office.com/g/qH2GiqGXuy), also linked on the SCC website at https://scc.ca.gov/public-notices/. Submissions will be accepted on a rolling basis throughout the year. All information received will be kept on file for at least one year from the date of this request. Conservancy staff will use this information in soliciting services, as needed, for upcoming Conservancy projects. We will also use this information in efforts to increase local community connections with our projects and in providing resources to share with grantees and other partners. The Conservancy has developed working relationships with a number of public and private entities through its work on coastal and watershed restoration efforts over the past 45 years. Advancing environmental protection and climate adaptation work requires diverse collaborations of public and private agencies, Indigenous peoples and Tribal Nations, landowners, and community members. We aim to foster collaboration between these groups to develop creative solutions to complex coastal issues. We hope this list will increase our awareness of the many groups, organizations, and individuals that should be involved in the development and implementation of our projects. State certified Small Businesses ("SB," including small business, minority and women-owned businesses) and Disabled Veteran Business Enterprises ("DVBE") are encouraged to submit. The Conservancy encourages all potential contractors to proactively engage with potential SB and DVBE subcontractors. We are soliciting consultants with experience and expertise in: 1. Surveying and mapping; 2. Construction project management; 3. Civil and hydrological engineering; 4. Habitat restoration design, permitting, construction, and monitoring; with a focus on designing for integrated habitats and multiple benefits; including specific expertise and project experience in specific habitat types and mixes of habitat palettes- marine, estuarine, riparian, upland, and watershed areas 5. Natural and nature-based shoreline protection design; including experimental techniques and work in less common habitat types such as rocky intertidal areas and oyster beds; 6. Wildfire risk reduction and management 7. Landscape architecture; with a focus on native and environmentally oriented designs, 8. Trail planning, design, and engineering; 9. Water quality assessment; 10. Geotechnical and geomorphic assessment; 11. Structural analyses; 12. Pre-project feasibility analyses; 13. Economic analyses; 14. Hazardous or toxic substance investigations; 15. Wetland, creek, watershed, intertidal and subtidal assessments; 16. Archaeological studies; 17. Environmental documentation and assessment under the California Environmental Quality Act and other environmental laws and regulation; 18. Climate change issues such as urban heat island effect, species migrations, seasonal coastal and fluvial flooding, and sea-level rise; 19. Botanical studies; 20. Agricultural studies; 21. Soil analyses; 22. Carbon analyses; 23. Biological investigations; 24. Natural resource permitting; 25. Site and land use planning; 26. Sea-level rise, marsh migration, and coastal erosion modeling; 27. Environmental monitoring; 28. Graphic design for interpretive signs; and 29. Other program-related environmental services, such as appraisals for resource conservation purposes. The Conservancy also seeks to identify individuals, firms, and community groups providing these services: 1. Community engagement planning and implementation 2. Justice, Equity, Diversity, Inclusion (JEDI) training and resources 3. Community engagement evaluation 4. Community-focused media and storytelling 5. Community-based restoration 6. Community-inclusive design planning 7. Local labor development and training 8. Traditional Ecological Knowledge To submit your qualifications and/or or organizational information, fill out the online Request for Qualifications and Information Submittal form (https://forms.office.com/g/qH2GiqGXuy), also linked on the SCC website at https://scc.ca.gov/public-notices/. More information can be found in the complete RFQI at https://scc.ca.gov/files/2025/09/2025-SCC-Full-RFQI.pdf. Please email taylor.samuelson (at) scc.ca.gov with any questions.

Description: The State of California, Office of Technology and Solutions Integration (OTSI), is releasing a Request for Proposal (RFP) #73040873 for System Development, Maintenance & Operations (SDMO) for the California Healthcare Eligibility, Enrollment and Retention System (CalHEERS). There will be a mandatory in-person Bidders Conference held on October 15, 2025. Please note: the conference will begin at 9:30 a.m. so please allow time for sign-in. The CalHEERS Project supports the enhancement, maintenance and operations, and on-going business of both Covered California and the Department of Health Care Services (DHCS). CalHEERS supports account creation, consumer application, eligibility rules, and health plan selection for insurance affordability programs, streamlining Californian's ability to research, compare, check their eligibility for, and purchase health coverage. CalHEERS interfaces with the Statewide Automated Welfare Systems (SAWS) for Modified Adjusted Gross Income (MAGI) Medi-Cal eligibility, enrollment and reporting, and provides data for potential eligibility to other programs such as, non-MAGI Medi-Cal, CalFresh, and California Work Opportunities and Responsibility for Kids (CalWORKS). 10/31/2025 - CalHEERS RFP #73040873 Addendum 1 and Responses Release 01 have been posted. Event Name: RFP-25-004 Publicist for CAC's 50th Anniversary

Pre Bid Conference.Location: Zoom
Pre Bid Conference.Comments: https://us06web.zoom.us/meeting/register/Qr4O4b7dRVa4g5A_SQi08w

Description: Please submit your bid proposal to Procurement@arts.ca.gov. Do review the Key Actions Dates listed on the attached RFP for all deadlines. BACKGROUND & PURPOSE The California Arts Council (CAC) celebrates its 50th Anniversary in 2026, marking five decades of advancing arts, culture, and creative expression across California. The agency seeks a qualified Publicist or Public Relations firm to lead a year-long communications and publicity effort to elevate public awareness of CAC's legacy, its awardees, grantees, and key initiatives that build a stronger California through the arts. This initiative will highlight: The 50th Anniversary Awards Ceremony and recognized artists; Grantee artistic events tied to CAC's 50th Anniversary and the America 250 celebration; Public messaging on how to donate to CAC through the Keep Arts in Schools and Arts License Plate programs (available through the California Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV)); Broader awareness of CAC's core programs including annual grants, Creative Economy, Cultural Districts, Arts in Corrections, and Arts in Health. Cal eProcure is the official solicitation site for RFP-25-004 Publicist. CAC encourage interested bidders to regularly visit the site to remain current on updates.

Event Name: RFI Unclaimed Cryptocurrency Asset Management
Description: The State Controller's Office (SCO) is seeking information regarding cryptocurrency custody platforms and related services for managing unclaimed crypto assets. This could be accomplished through a third-party custodian, implementing a direct custody model, or other proposed model. These services will ultimately allow the State to achieve its goals of providing secure, compliant, and scalable custody solutions for unclaimed cryptocurrency assets, Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs) and other emerging digital assets. This Request For Information (RFI) aims to explore custody, reporting, and asset transfer solutions to inform the State's management of digital wallets, adhering to all applicable legal and regulatory frameworks.

Hand delivered bids shall be placed in the DGS/OBAS Bid/Proposal Drop Box located in the lobby. Project comprises labor, material and services necessary for: Major components of Project Work consist of coordination of DOJ¿s removal and replacement of modular systems furniture which will include electrical connections and cabling of 112 workstations. In addition, two rooms will be converted to a training room with associated signage and mechanical work. Path of travel to the area of work will include one new fire rated door and signage. License required to bid the project: B Certificate of Reported Compliance (CRC) ¿ Fleet Vehicles: As a condition of Contract award, prior to Contract execution, Contractor shall submit copies of the valid CRCs for any fleet retained by the Contractor or any listed Subcontractor, for which any vehicles subject to the California Air Resources Board In-Use Off-Road Diesel Fueled Fleet Regulations, Section 2449(i), Title 12, California Code of Regulations, are used in the completion of the work included in the Contract. More information on the In-Use Off-Road Diesel-Fueled Fleets Regulation can be found at the following link: https://ww2.arb.ca.gov/our-work/programs/use-road-diesel-fueled-fleets-regulation Health and Safety Provisions: Contractor and all subcontractors shall abide by all health and safety mandates issued by federal, state, and local governments and/or public health officers as well as those issued by DGS, and worksite specific mandates. If multiple mandates exist, the Contractor and subcontractors shall abide by the most restrictive mandate. The term ¿employee¿, ¿worker¿, ¿state worker¿ or ¿state employee¿ in health and safety mandates includes contractor and subcontractor personnel. Costs associated with adhering to health and safety mandates are the responsibility of the Contractor. Contractor is responsible for the tracking and compliance of health and safety mandates and may be audited upon request. Successful bidder shall furnish payment and performance bonds, each in the amount of 100 percent of the Contract price. Prospective bidders must attend the mandatory prebid site inspection tour on November 5, 2025 at 10:00 a.m., at 1300 I St., Sacramento CA. The States requirements for Disabled Veteran Business Enterprise (DVBE) participation will be presented along with other contract requirements. Bidders are required to sign in upon arrival and sign out at the conclusion of the pre-bid site inspection. Attendance for the entire inspection is required in order for bidders to be eligible to submit a bid. Bid forms, plans, specifications, and addenda will be available for download at http://www.caleprocure.ca.gov/. Click on ¿Start Search.¿ In the Event name field, enter the project number and click search. While viewing the Event Details, click on ¿View Event Package¿ to view bid forms. It is recommended that all vendors register as a bidder through the Cal eProcure website at https://www.caleprocure.ca.gov/pages/bidder-vendor.aspx. This will allow for automatic notifications if there is any modification to the Event such as the posting of an addendum or additional documentation. Drawings and Project Manual may also be viewed through Builders' Exchanges. A public bid opening will be held on November 20, 2025 at 11:00 A.M. at 707 Third Street, West Sacramento, CA 95605. Bidders that choose to attend the bid opening shall check in with security in the lobby. A DGS representative will meet attendees in the lobby and escort all parties to the bid opening location. At the public bid opening, all bids received before 2:00 P.M., November 19, 2025 will be opened and recorded onto a Preliminary Bid Tabulation. Bidders do not need to attend the bid opening as the Preliminary Bid Tabulation will be emailed to participating contractors immediately after the bid opening. States estimated cost: $781,300. The term of this project is 124 calendar days. The States Project Director is Courtney Wetsell at (279) 799-4650.

Event Name: UCLA - 200 Medical Plaza, Third Floor Master Plan Study
Description: ADVERTISEMENT FOR EXECUTIVE ARCHITECT UCLA requests a written response to this Request for Qualifications (RFQ) to select an Executive Architect for the proposed 200 Medical Plaza, Third Floor Master Plan Study project (No. CP1416). The Peter Morton Medical Building is on the UCLA main medical campus at 200 UCLA Medical Plaza, Los Angeles, CA 90095. The building, constructed in 1990, is an approximately 360,000 gross square foot (GSF) outpatient medical facility with six stories and two subterranean levels. UCLA Health proposes to select an executive architect to plan the renovation of approximately 10,000 square feet on the 3rd floor of 200 Medical Plaza. The scope of work will include, but is not limited to, program improvements for the Medical Procedure Unit (MPU), infusion services, and other administrative and specialty clinic spaces. The renovations will also include improvements to patient treatment areas, exam rooms, and associated support service spaces. The construction cost for the project has not yet been determined; however, the entire renovation project is anticipated to be approximately $15 to $20 million, depending on the agreed-upon scope of work and the number of required separately permitted projects. Responses to this RFQ should demonstrate familiarity and experience in the planning, design, and construction administration of administrative, clinical, apheresis, and medical procedure suites, including security applications, equipment selection, and interior finishes appropriate for an MPU. Personnel proposed for this project must also demonstrate expertise in California's Department of Health Care Access and Information (HCAi) for OSHPD 3 (Clinic), National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) regulations, California Department of Public Health requirements (Title 22), and Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). The final selection and appointment of the architect for the proposed project are contingent upon project approval by the University of California Board of Regents or their delegated authority, and per the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA). The project is subject to review and approval by the UC Board of Regents or their delegated authority. The selection committee will base its review of the Executive Architect's submitted proposals and selection on the Selection Criteria form (Attachment A). This RFQ is for full design services, including the schematic design, design development, interior package, construction documents, cost estimate, assistance during the bid/award phase, construction administration, record documents, and project closeout; however, the University reserves the right to defer negotiations concerning services other than pre-design studies until the completion of the pre-design phase. The complete RFQ packet will be available at http://www.uclaplanroom.com on Thursday, October 30, 2025. Responses to the RFQ are due by or before 10:00 a.m. on Friday, November 21, 2025. To download the packet, you must create a login and password. Registration instructions are available at https://www.uclaplanroom.com/help/account.register. Once in the UCLA Planroom, click the "RFQ" tab and search for the project to download. Within the project "RFQ Document" tab, download (1) RFQ, (2) the Planroom RFQ-Upload Instructions, and (3) Appendix C and D Instructions. Every effort will be made to ensure that all persons have equal access to contracts and other business opportunities with the University within the limits imposed by law or University policy. Each Candidate Firm may be required to show evidence of its Equal Employment Opportunity policy. Important dates | Advertisement period: 10/30-11/21/25 | Questions due date:11/5/25 | Submission date:11/21/25 Peter E. Event Name: RFP-AIC-25-003 (Arts in Corrections

Pre Bid Conference.Location: https://us06web.zoom.us/meeting/register/l61bjNhTRGOzNkDE-sS4Og
Pre Bid Conference.Comments: Please register in advance.

Description: Please submit your bid proposal at Procurement@arts.ca.gov. BACKGROUND Administered by the CAC and made possible via ¿Memorandum of Understanding¿ with the CDCR, California's AIC program is designed to have a positive impact on the social and emotional well-being of people experiencing incarceration. Arts programs can increase critical thinking skills, build positive relationships, and promote healing and meaningful interactions between participants and their peers, facility staff, loved ones, and other individuals and community groups both inside and outside of the boundaries of their institutions. To learn more about the history of the program, visit the California Arts in Corrections website. The mission of CAC, a state agency, is strengthening arts, culture, and creative expression as the tools to cultivate a better California for all. The vision of CAC is a California where all people flourish with universal access to and participation in the arts. The values of the CAC are Community, Accessibility, Aesthetics, Autonomy with Accountability, Relevance, Equity, and Sustainability. To learn more about the CAC, visit our website. PURPOSE The California Arts Councils (CAC) Arts in Corrections (AIC) program contracts with organizations to provide arts workshops with teaching artists (referred to as Arts Providers for the purpose of this procurement) in cultural practices, design, literary, media, multidisciplinary, performing, traditional, and visual arts to people currently incarcerated in California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) adult facilities. SERVICE AREA For the service area, please review CDCR's Adult Institution List at: https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/adult-operations/list-of-adult-institutions/. BUDGET Proposals may be submitted for up to a maximum budget of $100,000 per proposed institution. The maximum budget per organization for all awarded current contracts may not exceed a total of $1,200,000 at any given time. IMPORTANT CAC strongly encourages interested bidders to regularly check the official solicitation posting in Cal eProcure for any changes or revisions to RFP-AIC-25-003.

Event Name: CDCR @ Corcoran Farming & Sustainable Land Management Lease ±398 Acres

Pre Bid Conference.Location: Location details provided only to confirmed and security cleared attendees who RSVP.

Description: The California Department of General Services (DGS) on the behalf of the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR), collectively referred to as ¿State¿, welcomes farming and land management lease proposals for approximately 398 acres at California State Prison, Corcoran (COR). The CDCR identified State-owned land available for farming activities at COR. The current land use includes a farming operation utilizing approximately three hundred and ninety-eight (398) acres to grow, rotate, maintain, and harvest sellable fodder crops. The COR land available for farming is identified in ¿Attachment A¿ (COR Farmable and Open Land). This opportunity requires Bidders to submit a ¿Sustainable Land Management Plan¿ (SLMP), the terms of which are negotiable provided the plan includes farming and land management activities on all COR open space, identified in ¿Attachment A¿. Bidders are not required to lease the COR Open Space in its entirety, but the SLMP must identify COR Open Space as being managed and maintained by the Lessee. A Bidder will be considered a ¿Qualified Bidder¿ after meeting all the Bidder requirements outlined in this RFP including, but not limited to, following instructions for submission, meeting established timelines, clearing a security background check, attending the mandatory walkthrough, and providing a SLMP that identifies how the Lessee will: 1) manage the COR Open Space in its entirety to eliminate maintenance and weed abatement costs for CDCR; and 2) Identify the Lessee¿s plan to grow, rotate, maintain, and harvest sellable fodder crops. Irrigation water is sourced by COR recycled effluent disposal. The State does not guarantee water availability, quality, or quantity. The State requires the Lessee to provide comprehensive, sustainable land management, and maintenance. Land management shall include weed abatement for fire control and mosquito abatement on all COR Open Space, whether farmed, grazed, vacant, leased, or not leased.

Contractor shall furnish all labor, equipment, tools, parts, materials, supplies, traffic control, travel, and incidentals necessary to provide Encampment Site Waste Removal and Cleanup Services in San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara Counites to Caltrans. The prime Contractor shall maintain the following certificates, trainings, permits and licenses for the duration of this Agreement: A Class A ¿ General Engineering Contractor License and a Hazardous Substance Removal (HAZ) Certification from California Contractor¿s State License Board (CSLB). Hazardous Materials Certificate of Registration issued by U.S. Department of Transportation Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration. Hazardous Materials Transportation License issued by CHP. Trauma Scene Waste Management Practitioner Certificate from State of California Department of Public Health, Medical Waste Management Program. Waste Tire Hauler Registration Decal for each vehicle with effective and expiration dates issued by Cal Recycle. Hazardous Waste Transporter Registration issued by the California Department of Toxic Substances Control. Confined Space Entry Certification, from each employee (in all classifications, see Contractor¿s Personnel Requirements in this Exhibit A, Scope of Work) as required by the Department of Industrial Relations, Division of Cal/OSHA. A permit and contractors program documents will also be required prior to the start of work. Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) Certificate of initial 40 hours of training and annual eight (8) Hour Refresher training from each employee (in all classifications, see Contractor¿s Personnel Requirements in this Exhibit A, Scope of Work), prior to the start of work. Contractor applying or spraying disinfectant shall possess a Pest Control Business Branch (PCB) or Main (PCM) license. A Qualified Applicator License (QAL) with Category K (health related) staff to oversee the business operations is required prior to the start of work. Both licenses are issued by Department of Pesticide Regulation (https://www.cdpr.ca.gov). Contractor applying or spraying disinfectant shall also be registered with each individual county agricultural commission where the disinfectant will be applied. Proof of these requirements shall be provided to Caltrans Contract Manager prior to applying or spraying disinfectant. Bidder shall possess at the time of bid submittal and for the duration of the Agreement, a valid and current Motor Carrier Permit issued from the California Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV). Bidder shall possess at the time of bid submittal, continuously thereafter, and for the duration of the Agreement, a valid and current registration with the Department of Industrial Relations (DIR). Event Name: IFB P2580020 Hazardous Waste Removal
Description: Invitation for Bid P2580020 Hazardous Waste Removal The California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW) is seeking a qualified business to provide hazardous waste removal services. The California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW) is tasked with excellent stewardship of the lands it holds in trust for the people of California. Like other public lands, CDFW properties are often inundated with trash and other refuse from illegal dumping, unauthorized camping, and other unauthorized activities. Hazardous materials pose a health and safety risk to the public and pollute the soil and water inhabited by the wildlife and fish that CDFW is entrusted to protect. Stewardship of public lands may involve the cleanup of hazardous materials. CDFW staff do not include classifications which possess the training and experience necessary to safely handle, remove, and dispose of hazardous materials. The overall objective of this Agreement is to maintain CDFW lands in an unpolluted state by removing and disposing of hazardous materials left from illegal dumping, unauthorized camping, and other unauthorized activities. Accomplishing this task will support CDFW¿s mission to manage its lands for their ecological values, their public use, and enjoyment. Please click "View Event Package" and download both documents for additional information.

The following procurement schedule has also been updated below: The anticipated schedule for this RFP is as follows: - Release: Tuesday, September 30, 2025. - Virtual Industry Forum: Friday, October 10, 2025, 10 a.m. Pacific Time. - Proposer Inquiries Deadline: Wednesday, October 24, 2025, 5 p.m. Pacific Time. - Addendum 1: Friday, October 24, 2025, 5 p.m. Pacific Time. - Deadline to Sign up for Site Visit: Thursday October 30, 2025 5 p.m. Pacific Time. - Site Visits: November 6, 2025. - Utility Relocation PG&E SR-46 Relocations Project. - Canal 9-22 and 6015 Embankment Project. - Well Abandonment Project. - Authority Responses Posted: Friday, October 31, 2025. - Proposer Inquiries for site visits and Addendum 1: Thursday, November 13, 2025. - Authority Responses to site visits and Addendum 1 Posted: Thursday, November 20, 2025 - Proposals due: Friday, December 5, 2025, 4 p.m. Pacific Time Questions regarding this RFP may be submitted to Emily A Morrison at ContractAdministration@hsr.ca.gov. 09/30/2025: The California High-Speed Rail Authority has issued a Request for Proposals (RFP) to request Proposals from qualified entities (Proposers) interested and able to provide a broad range of repair and minor construction activities on a task order basis. The work will occur in the counties of Merced, Madera, Fresno, Tulare, Kings, and Kern. The Authority intends to award a Multiple Award Task Order Contract (MATOC) to three pools of businesses: one pool of large business contractors for the entire geographic region, one pool of small business contractors with varying geographic scope, and one pool of authorized utility relocation contractors. The Authority seeks responses from large businesses as well as qualified Small Business (SB), Small Business for the Purpose of Public Works (SB-PW), Disadvantaged Business Enterprise (DBE), and Disabled Veteran Business Enterprise (DVBE) entities. The anticipated schedule for this RFEI is as follows: - Release: Tuesday, September 30, 2025 - Virtual Industry Forum: Friday, October 10, 2025, 10 a.m. Pacific Time - Proposer Inquiries Deadline: Wednesday, October 24, 2025, 5 p.m. Pacific Time - Authority Responses Posted: Wednesday, November 14, 2025 - Proposals due: Friday, December 5, 2025, 4 p.m. Pacific Time Questions regarding this RFP may be submitted to Emily A Morrison at ContractAdministration@hsr.ca.gov.

Event Name: Commencement 2026 Lighting, Audio and Visual Services
Description: California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (University) is seeking bids from a single service provider to plan, manage, coordinate, and oversee all aspects of Lighting, Audio and Visual Services for the 2026 Commencement Ceremonies as noted in Section III Scope of Work with estimated budget range One Hundred Thousand dollar (US$100,0000) to One Hundred and Thirty Thousand dollar (US$130,000). The University hosts annual Commencement ceremonies, consisting of multiple ceremonies at one (1) site, over a three (3) day period in May 2026. Commencement is scheduled for Friday, May 15, 2026, Saturday, May 16, 2026, and Sunday, May 17, 2026. Attendance is expected to reach approximately 8,500 guests per ceremony set for a total of four (4) sets, across three (3) days of Commencement. The University's objective is to provide graduates, their guests, and all attendees a safe and dignified Commencement. The University anticipates twelve (12) ceremonies in one (1) venue and events begin at 8:00 a.m., 12:00 p.m., 3:00 p.m., and 7:30 p.m., on Friday, May 15th, and at 8:00 a.m., 12:00 p.m., 4:00 p.m., and 7:30 p.m., May 16th and May 17th Saturday & Sunday, for all students graduating on those days. The lighting/audio visual company must have no less than five (5) years¿ experience in higher education events. DVBE 3% is required. Action Deadline Date Release of Request for Proposal (RFP) Monday, October 27, 2025 Last Day to Submit Questions (RFI) Thursday, November 20, 2025 Last Day to Post Addendum Tuesday, November 25 ,2025 RFP Due Date Monday, December 8, 2025 (2 PM P.S.T)

Description: The documents and files attached to this solicitation do not have any updates for digital accessibility at this time. Updates will be applied as soon as they are available. For an accessible version of solicitation documents published on this page, please submit a request at http://bit.ly/dpac-ada or call (916) 654-2852. Contractor shall furnish all labor, equipment, tools, parts, materials, supplies, traffic control, travel, and incidentals necessary to provide Encampment Site Waste Removal and Cleanup Services in Fresno, Kern, Kings, Tulare and Madera Counties to Caltrans. The Prime Contractor shall have at time of bid submittal, continually thereafter, and for the duration of the Agreement the following registration, certifications, permits and licenses: 1) A Class A ¿ General Engineering Contractor License and a Hazardous Substance Removal (HAZ) Certification from California Contractor¿s State License Board (CSLB). 2) Hazardous Materials Certificate of Registration issued by U.S. Department of Transportation Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration. 3) Hazardous Materials Transportation License issued by CHP. 4) Trauma Scene Waste Management Practitioner Certificate from State of California Department of Public Health, Medical Waste Management Program. 5) Waste Tire Hauler Registration Decal for each vehicle with effective and expiration dates issued by Cal Recycle. 6) Hazardous Waste Transporter Registration issued by the California Department of Toxic Substances Control. 7) Confined Space Entry Certification, from each employee (in all classifications) as required by the Department of Industrial Relations, Division of Occupational Safety and Health (Cal/OSHA) prior to the start of work. A permit and contractors program documents will also be required prior to the start of work. 8) Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) Certificate of initial 40 hours of training and annual eight (8) Hour Refresher training from each employee (in all classifications), prior to the start of work. 9) Contractor applying, or spraying disinfectant shall possess a Pest Control Business Branch (PCB) or Main (PCM) license. A Qualified Applicator License (QAL) with Category K (health related) staff to oversee the business operations prior to the start of work. Both of these licenses are issued by Department of Pesticide Regulation (https://www.cdpr.ca.gov). 10) Contractor applying, or spraying disinfectant shall also be registered with each individual county agricultural commission where the disinfectant will be applied. Proof of these requirements shall be provided to Caltrans Contract Manager prior to applying or spraying disinfectants. Bidder shall possess at the time of bid submittal, continuously thereafter, and for the duration of the Agreement, a valid and current Motor Carrier Permit issued from the California Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV). Bidder shall possess at the time of bid submittal, continuously thereafter, and for the duration of the Agreement, a valid and current registration with the Department of Industrial Relations (DIR). Caltrans will verify bidder¿s DIR registration; it is not necessary to provide a copy.

Costs associated with adhering to health and safety mandates are the responsibility of the Contractor. Contractor is responsible for the tracking and compliance of health and safety mandates and may be audited upon request. Successful bidder shall furnish payment and performance bonds, each in the amount of 100 percent of the Contract price. License required: CA Motor Carrier Permit Engineer's Estimate: $54,500.00 (this is an estimate and is not a guarantee of minimum service levels) Contract Term: 365 Calendar Days from Notice to Proceed Work Performance Period: 365 Calendar Days from Formal Start Work Date Job Showing: There will be no job showing. Prospective bidders are responsible for examining the site(s) and verifying all conditions before placing a bid. Instructions to Download Bid Package: Prospective bidders may examine and obtain the bid forms, specifications, plans and addenda (if any) by downloading this bid package from this website. Questions and Answers: Any discrepancies, omissions, ambiguities, or conflicts in or among the contract documents or doubts as to meeting shall be brought to the State's attention by emailing your questions to Sierra.Contracts@parks.ca.gov NO LATER THAN 2:00 p.m., on Monday, December 1, 2025. Answers will be provided by Addendum on this website on Wednesday, December 3, 2025, and it is the responsibility of the bidders to download any addendum as needed. Participation in Disabled Veteran Business Enterprise Program (DVBE): The minimum DVBE participation goal is 6%. THIS REQUIREMENT HAS BEEN WAIVED, but the incentive still applies. Please see DPR 479IW insert in bid booklet. Small Business and Small Business Subcontractor Participation: A five (5%) Small Business Preference will be granted to properly certified small businesses (a completed GSPD-05-105 form must be submitted with the bid proposal). Subject to Government Code Section 19134 - Personal services contracts entered into by a state agency in accordance with Section 19130 for persons providing janitorial and housekeeping services, custodians, food service workers, laundry workers, window cleaners, and security guard services shall include provisions for employee benefits and/or cash provisions to all covered employees as well as the 85 percent wage requirement. Bidders shall be in accordance with all sections of Government Code 19134. A Schedule of Employee Benefits Rates and Wages can be found on the CalHR website here https://www.calhr.ca.gov/state-hr-professionals/Pages/personal-services-contracts.aspx. Rate changes for benefits or wages occurring subsequent to issuance of a solicitation, but prior to the bid due date, shall be included in an addendum to the solicitation. Any Employee Benefit or wage rate changes (as published by CalHR) shall be given effect by contract amendment. If the contract term is less than one year, the Employee Benefit rates and wages in effect at the time of the bid due date shall apply for the entire contract term. The contract may adjust the Employee Benefits and/or Cash Payment amounts in the event of an amendment to the Schedule of Employee Benefit Rates published by CalHR during the term of the contact. Bids/Quotes Bidders must include the following information, in addition to all other requirements specified in the solicitation: 1. The method the bidder has chosen to fulfill the Employee Benefit component of GC § 19134, either by: a. providing Employee Benefits, or b. providing Cash Payments, or c. providing a combination of Employee Benefits and Cash Payments. 2. The total cost of Employee Benefits and/or Cash Payments based on the CalHR Rate Schedule in effect at the time the bids are due. For bidding purposes only, bidders may assume that the rates in effect at the time bids are due will be effective through the life of the contract, notwithstanding that the rates are in fact subject to change. 3. Before final execution of the contract, employers choosing to offer actual Employee Benefits instead of Cash Payment in lieu shall provide the names of insurance providers and terms of the coverage. Reporting and Monthly Statements The awarded contractor must submit monthly reports to the contracting agency during the term of the qualifying contract documenting compliance with GC Section 19134 as detailed below: 1. The number of covered employees who receive GC Section 19134 Employee Benefits and wages in the preceding month; 2. The name of the Covered Employee who received GC Section 19134 Employee Benefits and wages in the preceding month; 3. The number of hours each Covered Employee worked on the Qualifying Contract in the preceding month; 4. The amount paid to each Covered Employee for Employee Benefits and/or Cash Payments in the preceding month; 5. The hourly wage paid to each Covered Employee; 6. The total monthly cost of Employee Benefits and wages paid to each Covered Employee in the preceding month, excluding any administrative cost.

Description: STATE OF CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF GENERAL SERVICES REAL ESTATE SERVICES DIVISION PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND DEVELOPMENT BRANCH ADVERTISEMENT FOR BIDS CHILLER REPLACEMENT FREMONT CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION FREMONT, ALAMEDA COUNTY, CALIFORNIA CONTRACT NUMBER: 25-284062, PROJECT NUMBER: 9478 SEALED BIDS: DGS will receive sealed bids at 707 Third Street, West Sacramento, California 95605, before 2:00 P.M., December 10, 2025. Bids received after this date/time will not be considered received on time. Project comprises labor, material and services necessary for: Major components of Project Work consist of in-kind replacement for the majority of the central chiller water system which includes: two water cooled chillers, a refrigerant monitoring panel, two chiller water pumps, expansion tank, air separator, chemical pot feed, and selective replacement of chiller water piping to the new equipment. New equipment will not require new concrete pads as they will be mounted on their existing pad. The condenser water chemical treatment system will be replaced by a solid chemical water treatment system. License required to bid the project: B Certificate of Reported Compliance (CRC) ¿ Fleet Vehicles: As a condition of Contract award, prior to Contract execution, Contractor shall submit copies of the valid CRCs for any fleet retained by the Contractor or any listed Subcontractor, for which any vehicles subject to the California Air Resources Board In-Use Off-Road Diesel Fueled Fleet Regulations, Section 2449(i), Title 12, California Code of Regulations, are used in the completion of the work included in the Contract. More information on the In-Use Off-Road Diesel-Fueled Fleets Regulation can be found at the following link: https://ww2.arb.ca.gov/our-work/programs/use-road-diesel-fueled-fleets-regulation Health and Safety Provisions: Contractor and all subcontractors shall abide by all health and safety mandates issued by federal, state, and local governments and/or public health officers as well as those issued by DGS, and worksite specific mandates. If multiple mandates exist, the Contractor and subcontractors shall abide by the most restrictive mandate. The term ¿employee¿, ¿worker¿, ¿state worker¿ or ¿state employee¿ in health and safety mandates includes contractor and subcontractor personnel. Costs associated with adhering to health and safety mandates are the responsibility of the Contractor. Contractor is responsible for the tracking and compliance of health and safety mandates and may be audited upon request. Successful bidder shall furnish payment and performance bonds, each in the amount of 100 percent of the Contract price. Prospective bidders must attend the mandatory pre bid site inspection tour on November 19, 2025, at 10:00 A.M., at which time representatives of the State and prospective bidders shall meet at California School for the Deaf, Administration Office, located at 39350 Gallaudet Drive, Fremont, CA . The State¿s requirements for Disabled Veteran Business Enterprise (DVBE) participation and other Contract requirements will be presented. Prime Contractors are encouraged to have their Key Administrator and DVBE office coordinator attend to receive this information and to have their questions answered. Attendance for the entire inspection is required in order for bidders to be eligible to submit a bid. Bid forms, plans, specifications, and addenda will be available for download at http://www.caleprocure.ca.gov/. Click on ¿Start Search.¿ In the Event name field, enter the project number and click search. While viewing the Event Details, click on ¿View Event Package¿ to view bid forms. It is recommended that all vendors register as a bidder through the Cal eProcure website at https://www.caleprocure.ca.gov/pages/bidder-vendor.aspx. This will allow for automatic notifications if there is any modification to the Event such as the posting of an addendum or additional documentation. A public bid opening will be held on December 11, 2025 at 10:00 A.M. at 707 Third Street, West Sacramento, CA 95605. Bidders may attend virtually or in person. Bidders attending the bid opening in-person will need to meet and sign in at the security guard station in the lobby at the mailing address below. Bidders do not need to attend the bid opening as the Preliminary Bid Tabulation will be made available immediately after the bid opening is completed and it will be emailed to invited bidders. Two documents (one clean and one with redlines) have been uploaded for review. Please note that this Addendum supersedes the initial Release. The following procurement schedule has also been updated below: - IFB Released: September 11, 2025 - Addendum Released: October 9, 2025 - Addendum Questions from Firms due: October 16, 2025 - Authority Responses to Addendum Questions from Firms due: October 23, 2025 - Bids Due: November 6, 2025 by 12:00 p.m. - Bid Opening: November 6, 2025 at 2:00 p.m. - Notice of Proposed Award: Quarter 4, 2025 - Anticipated Contract Execution and Notice to Proceed: Quarter 4, 2025 10/03/2025: Round 1 of Questions and Responses have been posted here on Cal eProcure. 09/11/2025: The California High-Speed Rail Authority (Authority) has released an Invitation for Bids (IFB) to purchase commoditized Overhead Contact System (OCS) Poles materials, necessary to complete the First Construction Section of its high-speed rail track. No Pre-Bid Conference or Small Business Workshop is anticipated for this procurement. The timeline for this procurement is as follows: - IFB Released: September 11, 2025 - Bids Due: October 16, 2025 by 12:00 p.m. - Bid Opening: October 16, 2025 at 2:00 p.m. - Notice of Proposed Award: Quarter 4, 2025 - Contract Execution and Notice to Proceed: Quarter 4, 2025 Questions regarding this procurement should be submitted to Trevor Newhouse at materialpurchase@hsr.ca.gov or (916) 324-1541. 08/22/2025: The California High-Speed Rail Authority (Authority) will be releasing a new Invitation for Bids (IFB) to purchase commoditized Overhead Contact Systems (OCS) poles materials, necessary to complete the First Construction Segment of its high-speed rail track. A draft IFB is available for review as an attachment to this Cal-eProcure event. This draft IFB will be considered for approval and official release by the Authority's Board of Directors at its meeting scheduled for August 28, 2025, and is subject to change and approval by the Authority's Board of Directors. Posting of this draft IFB does not constitute acceptance of bids. The draft IFB or its approval, if granted by the Board of Directors, does not constitute a release of the final IFB. Release of the final IFB will occur via notice and posting on Cal-eProcure. Questions regarding this procurement may be submitted only upon final approval of IFB by the Board of Directors and release on the California State Contract Register. Each materials contract will be issued through multiple Notices to Proceed (NTPs) as described below. The estimated cumulative value for all materials contracts (steel OCS poles, rail, concrete ties, ballast, OCS system components, and fiber optic cable) is not-to-exceed $507.1 million for NTP 1. - NTP 1: The initial authorization to be issued for the manufacture and supply of Materials for use in construction on the 119-mile First Construction Section. - NTP 2: To be issued at the Authority's option for the manufacture and supply of Materials for use in construction on the northern extension (Merced to Madera). - NTP 3: To be issued at the Authority's option for the manufacture and supply of Materials for use in construction on the southern extension (Poplar Avenue in the County of Kern to Bakersfield). The scope of work for this specific procurement and resulting contract is to provide OCS poles materials, including baseplates, for use in construction on the 119-mile First Construction Section, with an estimated lead time of six to twelve weeks for NTP 1. General requirements for each material are provided in the IFB and draft agreement. The Contractor shall not perform any Work unless the Authority, in its sole discretion, issues a Notice to Proceed (NTP) and Purchase Order for such work. The actual amount of Work requested by the Authority is subject to the availability of funding. In addition, all materials must be newly manufactured goods and conform to the technical specifications provided by the Authority. All materials supplied must be Buy America and Build America, Buy America Act (BABA) compliant, in accordance with 49 U.S.C. § 22905 and 2 C.F.R. part 184. Information regarding the Pre-Bid Conference and Small Business Workshop is available on the Authority's Website. The anticipated schedule for this new procurement is as follows: IFB Release: September 2025 - Virtual Pre-Bid Conference: TBD - Bid Due/Opening Date: Q4 2025 - Notice of Proposed Award: Q4 2025 - Anticipated Contract Execution and Notice to Proceed: Q4 2025 Questions regarding this procurement should be submitted to Trevor Newhouse at materialpurchase@hsr.ca.gov or (916) 324-1541.
